ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This class was fully a virtual seminar.  Some assessments were done outside of class, but the majority of work was done in class or with a classmate.
live virtual lecture

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about basic Spanish grammar

I learned to speak up when knowing the answer or having something to say, especially since the class was conducted over zoom.  This class was obviously not the same over zoom, but I still got a lot out of the class and believe my Spanish progressed very nicely.
I learned a basic understanding of Spanish, including common vocabulary and basic grammatical structures.
I learned fundamental rules and words in Spanish. I learned about different phrases and ways to respond to situations.
Introduction to Spanish, grammar, memorization techniques, etc.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that it could be improved by class 5 times a week instead of three

A strength this course has is VHL, the nightly assignments require you to understand the topics and force you to focus. One weakness this course has is the amount of Spanish spoken informally.  I believe casually adopting a new language without stress would be helpful.  I would create weekly check-ins for this course just to make sure everyone in the class is comfortable with their proficiency in an informal setting.
The course was run very well, and I wouldn't change anything about it.

I was glad that the Proyecto Cultural is a component of the course. It allowed me to learn more about the varying cultures of Spanish-speaking countries. It was also very helpful to have all of the assignments and learning goals available in the syllabus. It left no ambiguity with what I should be learning at any time.
I liked how there were tests throughout the semester rather than one cumulative final  it forced me to actually learn the material as we were covering it.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: More break out sessions would be beneficial to practice speaking

Overall, this class was managed very well. I learned a lot and had a smile on my face for virtually the entire class period.  The class discussions were great and for the most part included everyone.  I think more oral assignments should be included, those being live, not recorded.  It would require students to proactively think instead of pressing, "stop recording," and trying over and over again with no stress.

Having synchronous class only MWF versus every day of the week was really helpful, and when we were meeting virtually, the level of engagement still remained high because there were so few of us in the class. Professor Sabe was also great about talking to us all.
I liked the small class size which really helped me have my questions answered.
I feel like we always had secret assignments that I was forgetting about, since we didn't meet for class everyday and the assignments were all online.

I think more of the new vocabulary/grammatical structures could have been covered during class, as we often had to learn these on our own. I liked how some days were synchronous/some were asynchronous, as I think it allowed me to digest the new material better.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to anyone who has taken a small amount of Spanish in the past and wants to proceed with the language.  If you have never taken Spanish, I would buckle up, because this class is very fast-paced and there is no time to take a break.
Yes, this is a good class to take to fulfill your language requirement.
I would wholeheartedly recommend this course for anyone interested in learning Spanish. It is very well-structured and I learned a lot more than the two years of Spanish I took during high school.
I would say that I greatly enjoyed the class but it was definitely more work-intensive than some of the intro classes in the other language departments.
